stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who delivered vaginally 4 hours ago. Based on the assessment data in the EHR, determine which nursing interventions are indicated and which are contraindicated. Match each nursing intervention to its appropriate category.

rationale.correct: Administering Labetalol IV push is indicated because the patient's blood pressure is elevated (160/100 mmHg) and the provider has ordered labetalol PRN for SBP >160. Initiating seizure precautions is indicated due to the patient's elevated blood pressure, headache, blurred vision, and proteinuria, which are all signs of preeclampsia and increase the risk of seizure. Massaging the fundus is indicated because it is boggy and displaced, suggesting uterine atony, which can lead to postpartum hemorrhage. Monitoring urine output is indicated due to the risk of decreased renal perfusion associated with preeclampsia.

mnemonic.title: HELLP
mnemonic.expansion: Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets – Remember to assess for HELLP syndrome in patients with preeclampsia.

rationale.incorrect: Elevating the head of the bed to a flat position is contraindicated. A semi-Fowler's position would be more appropriate to reduce pressure on the diaphragm and improve respiratory effort, especially with elevated blood pressure. Encouraging ambulation is contraindicated at this time. The patient's preeclampsia symptoms (headache, blurred vision, and elevated BP) and risk for seizure warrant bed rest to prevent falls and further complications.

questionTrap.trap: Students might focus solely on the postpartum hemorrhage risk and miss the subtle signs of worsening preeclampsia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the importance of assessing all systems and recognizing that preeclampsia can manifest or worsen postpartum. Encourage students to consider the patient's complete clinical picture, including vital signs, lab values, and subjective symptoms.

clinicalPearls: Preeclampsia can occur postpartum, even if it wasn't present during pregnancy.
Uterine atony is a primary cause of postpartum hemorrhage and requires prompt intervention.

itemContext.sbar: 0700 Report: Maria Rodriguez, a 28-year-old G1P1, delivered vaginally at 0300 after a 12-hour labor. Epidural was removed at 0400. At 0600, assessment revealed a boggy fundus, 2 cm above the umbilicus and displaced to the right. She has moderate lochia rubra with several quarter-sized clots. Her BP is 160/100, HR 98, RR 20, Temp 37.2°C (99°F), and O2 sat 98% on room air. Patient reports a headache and blurred vision. Foley catheter is in place with an output of 30 mL/hr. She states she feels anxious and overwhelmed. Recent lab work shows elevated urine protein. The provider was notified of the elevated BP and headache at 0630 and ordered labetalol 20mg IV push q10 min PRN SBP>160. Patient is on droplet precautions due to elevated blood pressure and potential for preeclampsia; continue to monitor for signs of pulmonary edema. No other new orders received.
